abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment rates the outcome
            moderately satisfactory for the Third Social Investment Fund
            and the Fourth Social Investment Fund projects for Honduras.
            The central objective of Honduran Social investment Fund
            (FHIS) of supporting the government's poverty
            alleviation strategy was relevant and in line with the
            Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper (PRSP) and the Country
            Assistance Strategy (CAS). The assessment rates overall
            sustainability as unlikely for both credits. Although most
            FHIS projects are reported (in project evaluations) to be in
            use, the same evaluations also note that they are often not
            used in full and there were many problems with the quality
            of subprojects and with their maintenance. Overall Bank
            performance was satisfactory with caveats. Bank staff was
            overoptimistic about the possibilities of securing
            maintenance, first by expecting too much from line
            ministries and later by relying too heavily on user
            committees. The experience of the two projects offers three
            lessons: While social funds are attractive for donors and
            can initially be successful in providing remote communities
            access to basic health and educational facilities, the
            experience of the Honduras social fund shows that they are
            not a long-term sustainable solution for providing basic
            infrastructure. Because of the apparent success in its core
            activity of financing basic infrastructure projects, FHIS
            has been and continues to be attractive for donors for
            programs that do not belong to the core activity. FHIS had a
            positive institutional development impact in promoting
            decentralization by helping to strengthen local government
            capacities in project planning and implementation.
